release.name: OrientDB 3.2.24
release.body:
# Changes 
## Core
 - Optimized OResult to load records lazily
 - Optimized OResult to avoid early load of link in properties
 - Minor optimizations in the query engine runtime 
 - Fix insert into index step to use the right value
 - Minor dependencies updates
 - Fix regression in rid comparison in case of embedded query
 - Fix regression in direct insert into index query
 - Fix regression in update index step
 - Avoid storage to go in read only mode if index key type validation fails
release.short_description_html:
Changes

Core

  • Optimized OResult to load records lazily
  • Optimized OResult to avoid early load of link in properties
  • Minor optimizations in the query engine runtime
  • Fix insert into index step to use …

commits.message: OrientDB prepare for next development iteration

payload.description: OrientDB is the most versatile DBMS supporting Graph, Document, Reactive, Full-Text and Geospatial models in one Multi-Model product. OrientDB can run distributed (Multi-Master), supports SQL, ACID Transactions, Full-Text indexing and Reactive Queries.

issue.title: Really slow drop of indexes
issue.body:
### OrientDB Version: 3.2.0 ### Java Version: openjdk version "11.0.11" ### OS: Ubuntu 21.04 ## Expected behavior To drop indexes instantaneously (or fast enough). ## Actual behavior ### Discussed in https://github.com/orientechnologies/orientdb/discussions/9592
Originally posted by **johny65** April 27, 2021 Is it normal to take so much time to drop an index? I have an index over 3 millions of vertices, dropping it takes almost 7 minutes: Server side script executed in 270,993988 sec(s). Value returned is: [][Started multi-line command. Type just 'end' to finish and execute] I have a migrated database with several auxiliary indexes for the migration process, deleting all of those auxiliary indexes takes an hour or more. Even so, if I don't run the drop commands in separate scripts, then all my RAM is exhausted. Is this an issue or is it normal? (Using 3.1.x version).
I have to add that yesterday I had a case where dropping an index took more than 5 hours! ``` orientdb {db=heimdall}> drop index myindex; Removing index... Dropped index in 20118,683594 sec(s). Index removed successfully ``` ## Steps to reproduce Create a large index and drop it.

issue.body:
### OrientDB Version: 3.2.0 ### Java Version: openjdk version "11.0.11" ### OS: Ubuntu 21.04 ## Expected behavior To drop indexes instantaneously (or fast enough). ## Actual behavior ### Discussed in https://github.com/orientechnologies/orientdb/discussions/9592
Originally posted by **johny65** April 27, 2021 Is it normal to take so much time to drop an index? I have an index over 3 millions of vertices, dropping it takes almost 7 minutes: Server side script executed in 270,993988 sec(s). Value returned is: [][Started multi-line command. Type just 'end' to finish and execute] I have a migrated database with several auxiliary indexes for the migration process, deleting all of those auxiliary indexes takes an hour or more. Even so, if I don't run the drop commands in separate scripts, then all my RAM is exhausted. Is this an issue or is it normal? (Using 3.1.x version).
I have to add that yesterday I had a case where dropping an index took more than 5 hours! ``` orientdb {db=heimdall}> drop index myindex; Removing index... Dropped index in 20118,683594 sec(s). Index removed successfully ``` ## Steps to reproduce Create a large index and drop it.

comment.body:
Hi,

Closing this, please re-open if you can still reproduce the problem.

test: add test cases for insert into index operations
refactor: removed usage of deprecated API from test cases
fix: correct regression in direct insert into index query
refactor: removed deprecated APIs use from tests
refactor: generalized databsae inizialization in unit tests
refactor: removed old API from core test cases

issue.title: Cannot create index BY VALUE on a EMBEDDEDMAP property with an EMBEDDED* Linked_Type
issue.body:
### OrientDB Version: 3.0

## Expected behavior  
creation of an index on the property values

## Actual behavior  
Get a java.lang.NullPointerException
Index not created

## Steps to reproduce  

Here is a simple SQL script to reproduce the error :
```
CREATE CLASS Test EXTENDS V
CREATE PROPERTY Test.map EMBEDDEDMAP EMBEDDEDLIST
CREATE INDEX testIndex ON Test (map BY VALUE) NOTUNIQUE
```

commits.message: fix: correct rid comparation in case of embedded query

issue.title: The count query takes an excessive amount of time to complete
issue.body:
### OrientDB Version: 3.2.19  
### Java Version: java version "1.8.0_261" Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (build 1.8.0_261-b12) Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (build 25.261-b12, mixed mode)  
### OS: Ubuntu 22

I'm using a 4 nodes cluster each one with 32 CPU and 16Gb. Orientdb started and running with dserver.sh on each node

## Expected behavior  
The count query should return the result in a reasonable amount of time, considering the size of the graph.

## Actual behavior  
Executing count queries in OrientDB with a large number of vertices (over 200,000). The count query takes an excessive amount of time to complete.

##Steps to Reproduce:
1. Set up a graph database in OrientDB with over 200,000 vertices.
2. Execute a count query on the vertices, such as "SELECT COUNT(1) FROM V".

Additional Notes:
I have observed that the performance issue becomes more noticeable as the number of vertices increases. Other types of queries perform well, but count queries specifically exhibit this problem.
How does it changes when the vertex has one or more unique indexes?

Please let me know if any additional information or test cases are needed to investigate and address this performance issue.

Thank you.
Gianluca Valentini

comment.body:
Hi,

There have been improvement on this in 3.2.23, can you double check that version ?

Regards

issue.title: .size() function gives wrong value
issue.body:
### OrientDB Version: 3.2.5
### Java Version: 8
### OS: Windows server 2019

issue.title: Many links lead to https://orientdb.com / instead of https://orientdb.org/
issue.body:
Hello

We (https://page.hyoo.ru /#!=2xoa2z_ljovtv) we plan to use orientdb in our projects as a 2 alternative database. The database is currently being studied

We are faced with the fact that many links lead to https://orientdb.com / instead of https://orientdb.org/

Both on the website and in the Studio. Can you please correct it?

OrientDB installed latest from Docker

![image](https://github.com/orientechnologies/orientdb/assets/32732179/328fddc8-d0af-4c3d-958e-c694be5bff5e)

issue.title: Wrong last()  result after Database repair
issue.body:
### OrientDB Version: 3.2.18
### Java Version: 8  
### OS: Docker Linux  

## Expected behavior  
If i have node 0 and make links in time with node 1  , after that  with node 2 and node 3, the function return last(out("son")) = node 3

## Actual behavior  
After running REPAIR DATABASE with the parameters from documentation, the REPAIR seems to relink in other order.

I don't know if it is because of performance reasons the initial order is not maintained or is a normal behavior and i shouldn't use last in this case.

last returns NODE 3 (ignore @rid from picture, it is the same picture for example)

![beforerepair](https://github.com/orientechnologies/orientdb/assets/7643185/c22678d3-d76d-4602-bed8-ac2a4eed7d9c)

After repair last return NODE 1
![afterrepair](https://github.com/orientechnologies/orientdb/assets/7643185/93affa63-73b8-4751-bd0a-54db7ef7aa0e)
